I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) 2003 Country Strategy and Program Update for the 
Islamic Republic of Pakistan1 includes the provision of an advisory technical assistance (TA) for 
Capacity Building of Sindh Devolved Social Services,2 proposed for ADB financing in 2004. 
During a review mission of the Sindh Devolved Social Services Program (DSSP)3 in March 
2004, the Sindh provincial government (SPG) indicated that it had adequate resources for 
capacity building in the education and health sectors under the ADB-financed TA loan but still 
required  assistance  for  water  supply  and  sanitation  (WSS)  and  solid  waste  management 
(SWM),  referred  to  as  environmental  management.  The  TA  is  crucial,  as  it  will  help  the 
Government  improve  the  policy  framework  and  strategic  planning  in  environmental 
management, which is a condition for the second and third tranche release of the DSSP. The 
TA will pave the way for ADB assistance of urban improvements in Sindh. The ADB Fact-
Finding Mission visited Pakistan on 12–16 July 2004, reaching a preliminary understanding with 
the  Government  on  the  goals,  scope,  terms  of  reference  of  the  TA,  implementation,  and 
financing arrangements.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Lack of Adequate WSS Schemes. Pakistan has over 141 million people, and one of its 
most pressing needs over the next quarter century will be to manage a rapidly increasing 
population and to provide basic amenities: food, domestic water supply, waste management 
and power requirements. Significant disparities in average income levels for rural and urban 
populations  exist  throughout  Sindh,4  as  well  as  the  rest  of  the  country;5  consequently, 
differences in the availability of services are also significant. Two thirds of Sindh lies either in the 
brackish water zone or in the desert zone; only 17%  lies in the freshwater zone. Rainfall is low, 
and most rural people extract water from the Indus River and its irrigation system. In rural and 
urban areas, drinking water is often polluted and distributed without treatment. In rural areas, 
piped water supply covers 14% and hand pumps 41%; the remaining 45% of households rely on 
unsafe water such as uncovered wells, rivers, and rain- or canal-fed ponds. Karachi’s bulk water 
supply  is  only  sufficient  to  support  66%  of  its  population,  while  the  remaining  population 
depends on water vendors.6 Water and sanitation infrastructure has often been developed 
without a master plan or an analysis of operation and maintenance (O&M) costs, so that several 
schemes  have  been  abandoned.  Sewage  treatment  is  generally  absent  throughout  Sindh, 
except in Karachi.7 In rural Sindh, 53% of the population lacks access to basic sanitation 
facilities. The lowest-income groups, especially women and children, face serious problems in 
meeting their water supply needs, and water-related diseases are common.

4  Sindh is one of Pakistan’s four administrative provinces, covering 140,900 km2 (17.7% of the total area) and with a 
population of 32.3 million (22.9% of the total). 
5  Half of Sindh’s population is urban, of which 35.2% is poor, living on less than a dollar a day, while 39.8% of the 
rural population is poor (ADB. 2001. Poverty Assessment Report. Manila).  
6  Water supply is mostly from surface water sources, although groundwater supplies account for up to 0.2 million 
gallons a day. The estimated demand is 265–300 million gallons per day, of which approximately 70% is treated in 
filtration plants. Six water treatment plants exist and one more is planned. Water losses due to the deterioration of 
pipelines have been estimated at 30–35% of the total water extracted.  
7  An estimated 50–60% of the city’s sewage is treated; the remainder is discharged to the sea untreated. Karachi’s 
three operating sewage treatment plants, with a capacity of 150 million gallons a day, suffer operational problems. 
Karachi has no dedicated treatment plant for industrial waste, which is disposed of untreated.

2  
 
3.  Poor SWM. Solid waste generated in Pakistan ranges from 0.283 to 0.612 kg per capita 
per day, with a reported growth rate of 2.4% per year. Despite marginal improvements reported 
by the United Nations Development Programme and Japan International Cooperation Agency 
(JICA),8 SWM is becoming an issue of growing concern throughout Pakistan, especially in 
Sindh, where solid waste is randomly disposed of in open land and drains or burned in an 
uncontrolled manner. Informal recycling systems9 cover only certain types of waste10 and suffer 
from high inefficiencies, while hazardous pollutants are disposed of in a random and unsafe 
manner. Karachi and Hyderabad have a substantial number of registered industries, but also 
many smaller businesses operating without a license, which often generate industrial, toxic, and 
hazardous waste, potentially discharged into the sewage system with other domestic waste. 
Sindh has a number of inpatient hospitals, clinics, and small hospitals. Except for a few hospital 
incinerators in Karachi,11 medical facilities are often not properly equipped; thus, up to 65% of 
hazardous clinical waste is disposed of in domestic landfill sites. The poor are more exposed 
than others to health hazards arising from poor hygienic and toxic conditions, through living or 
working in contaminated environments. 
 
4.  Weak Institutional Capacity and Regulatory and Policy Framework. Several federal 
and  Sindh  water  laws12  have  been  enacted,  including  the  National  Environmental  Quality 
Standards, but enforcement has been limited. The first comprehensive national water policy is 
to  be  presented  for  Cabinet  approval  in  2004.  The  Pakistan  water  sector  strategy  and 
associated medium-term investment plan are in preparation. They will identify key issues and 
objectives for the water sector and propose plans to develop and manage water resources in all 
water subsectors at a national level. Despite efforts from various agencies, no national or 
provincial  policies  or  standards  for  solid  waste  disposal  have  been  promulgated.13  Local 
initiatives14 have generally been isolated efforts. Policies and strategies at national level may not 
address provincial needs and conditions. The institutional context of SWM and WSS is in flux. 
Under Pakistan’s Devolution Plan, district governments headed by the taluka or town nazims 
are responsible for planning, investment, and control of municipal services, including water 
supply, sanitation, and solid waste disposal. After devolution, the Public Health Engineering 
Department (PHED) merged with the Local Government Department, and responsibilities for 
planning and operating schemes were devolved to the tehsil municipal administrations (TMAs). 
Partly  due  to  lack  of  funds  and  capacity  to  execute  these  new  responsibilities  and  partly 
because PHED, through its Hyderabad technical division and district support units, continues to 
exert influence and manage the technical, financial, and administrative aspects of WSS, the 
TMAs  have  not  properly  assumed  the  responsibilities  envisaged  under  the  Sindh  Local

by poor recovery of bills, overstaffing, and theft of water.  
  
5.  Lack of Private Sector Participation. Although the Sindh Local Government Ordinance 
(2001)  envisages  substantial  public-private  partnerships  for  improving  service  delivery  and 
stresses ways of involving communities, there is little evidence of practical implementation of 
these principles to encourage private investors in the water utilities and SWM sectors.15 The 
water  agencies  and  municipal  bodies  traditionally  charged  with  managing  water  supply, 
wastewater,  and  solid  waste  suffer  from  financial  weaknesses  that  prevent  them  from 
generating capital to rehabilitate, improve and expand infrastructure and facilities.16 So far, 
private sector participation in Sindh has been limited, with some WSS construction efforts by 
rural community-based organizations (CBOs) 17, a few community-level solid waste collection 
activities, and a few private contracts for Karachi’s larger treatment and disposal operations.18 
The Government recognizes that private sector resources are needed to meet the demands of 
growing urban and rural communities and  to safeguard the environment; yet, inadequate cost 
recovery mechanisms may deter further involvement of the private sector.  
 
6.   Lessons from Previous Experience. Lessons derived from previous ADB projects in 
the sector in Sindh show that (i) urban upgrading should be designed from a plan that integrates 
all aspects of urban infrastructure and involves participation of beneficiaries, (ii) institutional 
capacity must be present, and (iii) the financial framework must be in place to ensure long-term 
sustainability. This TA is intended to enhance ongoing institutional restructuring and formulate 
development policies, strategies, and action plans for WSS and SWM in Sindh. The TA will 
identify planning principles to enhance community and stakeholder participation, options, and 
opportunities to increase cost recovery through an effective tariff system, improve financial 
management and build private sector confidence for future investment, and identify technical 
and management choices for environmental sustainability. The TA supports Pakistan’s Ten-
Year Perspective Development Plan (2001-2011). 17 The TA is consistent with ADB’s Country 
Strategy  and  Program  (2002-2006),19  which  emphasizes  supporting  governance  reform 
programs and devolution, reducing rural poverty, providing basic urban services and water, and 
increasing efforts toward sustainable environmental management.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
7.  The TA goal is to improve sustainable environmental management, health, and living 
conditions in Sindh. The TA aims to help the Government develop a participatory strategic 
planning framework to improve rural and urban environmental conditions in Sindh. Specific 
outputs  designed  to  achieve  this  goal  and  purpose  are  (i)  a  cross-sectoral  review  of 
developments, issues, and concerns in the SWM and WSS sectors; (ii) policies, strategies, and 
action plans for SWM and WSS sectors in the different districts of Sindh; and (iii) an appropriate

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  Sectoral Review and Development of SWM and WSS. Activities will comprise (i) 
making  a  comprehensive  analysis  of  practices,  activities,  stakeholders,  and  institutional 
regulatory setup; (ii) verifying data and gap analysis; (iii) developing a methodology for strategic 
planning  through  consensus;  (iv)  preparing  a  participatory  issue  assessment;  and  (vi) 
formulating SWM and WSS policies for Sindh.  
 
9.  Strategic Planning. The TA will set the stage for strategic planning in SWM and WSS 
sectors in Sindh over the medium term. Activities will include (i) developing strategic planning 
principles and options; (ii) preparing a framework for an efficient and responsive organizational 
structure, and (iii) formulating strategies and action plans for SWM and WSS in Sindh, based on 
identified needs of the TMAs. Policies and strategies will provide sectoral overall development 
aims and frameworks for action, setting out the main principles surrounding development of 
selected practices. The TA envisages participatory development of policies and strategies at a 
provincial level, where the TMAs will be instrumental in decision-making. The medium term 
plans for SWM and WSS will be developed for individual TMAs, according to their specific 
needs and objectives, and collected into a single document for Sindh20. 
 
10.  Stakeholder Participation. To combine professional analysis with local knowledge to 
obtain  outputs  widely  accepted  among  stakeholders,  strategic  planning  will  (i)  identify  key 
stakeholders  and  assess  issues  in  consultation  with  towns  and  talukas,  and  (ii)  conduct 
preliminary technical and organizational workshops to encompass all aspects of SWM and WSS 
and  develop  good  understanding  of  and  agreement  over  outstanding  issues.  Stakeholder 
endorsement of draft SWM and WSS policies, strategies, and action plans will be sought 
following consultation and stakeholder workshops. Schemes for beneficiary communities and 
CBOs will be identified  to encourage participation and ownership throughout planning, design, 
implementation, and O&M. 
 
11.  Appropriate Tariff Selection. The Government recognizes that a sound tariff policy for 
SWM and WSS is integral to achieving sustainable schemes. A cost-effective and sustainable 
system is essential in Sindh, particularly in urban areas facing rapid deterioration of resources, 
yet poverty considerations must be incorporated into the study. Specific activities will include (i) 
studying existing tariff and user charges, and reviewing data on social and financial objectives, 
budgetary  constraints,  and  willingness  to  pay;  (ii)  conceptualizing  institutional  and  legal 
frameworks for the tariff approval process and the tariff collection and administration systems in 
rural and urban areas; and (iii) developing a tariff calculation methodology and associated 
guidelines to meet local needs and conditions.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000 equivalent, comprising $262,000 in 
foreign exchange costs and $238,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will finance 
$400,000 equivalent, which will cover the entire foreign exchange cost, and $138,000 equivalent 
in local currency costs. The Government will contribute the remaining $100,000, which will

include office accommodation, transportation, counterpart staff, background reports, studies, 
and workshop facilities. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s funding program. 
The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The Finance Department of SPG, the Executing Agency for the DSSP, will be the 
Executing Agency for the TA, while the Local Government Department (LGD) of SPG will be the 
Implementing Agency. The TA activities will be assisted by the DSSP support unit. LGD will 
designate a senior staff member to coordinate the TA, and assign counterpart staff to assist the 
consultants. District governments will select focal points for this TA, coordinating activities with 
towns and  talukas. These will liaise closely with the consultants and provide regular advice and 
inputs to the TA. Consistent with DSSP activities, the government will set up a TA advisory 
committee to periodically review TA progress and guide implementation. The committee will 
comprise  senior  government  representatives  from  relevant  government  agencies,  including 
district government and TMA officials, LGD, Planning and Development Department of SPG, 
Sindh  Environmental  Protection  Agency,  Finance  Department,  Health  Department  of  SPG, 
Public Health Engineering Department of LGD, and aid agencies. Suitably furnished office 
space with utilities and telecommunications access, local transport for consultants, maps, data, 
and related documents required by the TA will be provided by LGD.  
 
14.  The TA will be implemented over 6 months, from February 2005 to July 2005. A team of 
international and domestic consultants will be selected and engaged by ADB to provide a total 
of 37 person-months’ consulting services—11 person-months’ international and 26 person-
months’ domestic. The consultants will be selected and engaged by ADB in accordance with the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by Asian Development Bank and Its Borrowers (2002) 
and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. The 
outline terms of reference for TA consultants and indicative scheduling are in Appendixes 3 and 
4, respectively. The international consultants will include experts in SWM, WSS, and financial 
and economic analysis. The domestic consultants will include experts in SWM, WSS, policies, 
tariff economics, institutional and legal aspects, socioeconomic analysis and environmental 
management. ADB’s simplified technical proposal approach will be used to select consultants.  
 
15.  The consultants will submit four major reports: (i) an inception report no later than 4 
weeks after services start; (ii) a midterm report no later than the end of the third month; (iii) a 
draft final report at the end of the fifth month; and (iv) a final report within 3 weeks upon receipt 
of comments from the Government and ADB on the draft final report. The consultants will 
submit short monthly progress reports summarizing project activities, issues, and constraints. 
Tripartite meetings will be held among ADB, the Government, and consultants to review the 
inception and draft final reports. Key deliverables from this TA will be translated by consultants 
to facilitate their review by Government and other stakeholders. On approval, SWM and WSS 
policies, strategies and action plans for Sindh will be disseminated through official publication 
channels and through print and electronic media. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Pakistan for Capacity Building for Environmental Management in Sindh, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  consultants  will  perform  the  following  tasks  in  close  consultation  with  the 
responsible government departments and agencies at the provincial, district, town and union 
council  levels  to  ensure  full  acceptance  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  outcome.  The 
consultants will undertake the following tasks: 
 
A.  Understanding Shortfalls and Constraints of Solid Waste Management and Water 
Supply and Sanitation in Sindh 
(i)  Review and analyze previous studies at national and provincial level: reports, 
data, project and related information, including lessons learned from solid waste 
management (SWM) and water supply and sanitation (WSS) projects. 
(ii)  Examine  socioeconomic  data  on  priority  areas  and  assess  the  major  social 
issues  and  constraints.  Review  social  aspects  related  to  SWM  and  WSS, 
including patterns of waste generation and handling of households and other 
users, community-based waste management and participation, and the social 
conditions of waste workers and scavengers. Review the orientation of SWM and 
WSS  services  to  address  the  needs  and  demands  of  population;  public 
awareness  of  solid  waste  and  waterborne  problems  and  priorities;  working 
conditions (safety, sanitation, workload), sanitary and environmental conditions.  
(iii)  Review studies determining solid waste and sewage quantities and composition 
in rural and urban areas (e.g., generation, transfer, waste disposal). 
(iv)  Determine the budget, scope, and coverage targets of ongoing and planned 
SWM and WSS projects financed by Government and provincial departments, 
various agencies and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) (service coverage; 
service level, effectiveness, and efficiency of waste collection of street sweeping 
and  cleansing  services;  resource  recovery  efficiency  and  targets;  and 
effectiveness and efficiency of water distribution and sanitation system).  
(v)  Review  solid  waste  and  WSS  operations  and  technologies  in  use  in  Sindh. 
Assess their positive impact on health and environment, capacity, and range of 
users. 
(vi)  Review data leading to predictions of future capacity requirements and future 
demand for Sindh SWM and WSS services, to include population predictions, 
socioeconomic conditions, and projected service coverage.  
(vii)  Review SWM- and WSS-related legislation and assess enforcement success and 
extent: laws, regulations, standards, and guidelines at the national, provincial, 
district, and local levels. 
(viii)  Review private sector participation in SWM and WSS: type and nature of existing 
investments, tendering requirements, contract periods, etc. 
(ix)  Evaluate  to  date  and  ongoing  public  awareness  and  participation  to  include 
practices in supply, storage, and discharge; participation in primary, secondary 
and  tertiary  collection;  willingness  to  pay  fees;  complaints;  fines.  Evaluate 
decision makers’ awareness of key SWM and WSS issues, political priorities, 
and accountability. 
(x)  Analyze revenue and expenditure of existing SWM and WSS services: budget 
allocation, fee schedules, affordability and value, subsidy schemes, and tariffs. 
(xi)  Analyze existing SWM and WSS administrative support capability with respect to 
planning, personnel administration, public relations, and health education.

12  Appendix 3 
(xii)  Analyze the SWM and WSS sector institutional and organizational setup as well 
as coordination, if any, with local groups (local agencies, CBOs, NGOs, private 
sector, etc). 
(xiii)  Devise  hands-on  assessment  survey  questionnaire,  checklist,  and  any  other 
appropriate method for (a) filling gaps in data collection; and (b) verifying  data 
(willingness to pay surveys, operational setup, realistic data coverage in rural 
areas,  etc.).  Select  representative  sample  areas  and  guide  local  waste 
management and SWM experts in conducting the task.  
 
B.  Consensus Building  
(i)  Identify  individuals  to  represent  the  various  stakeholder  groups.  Under  the 
devolution process in Pakistan, towns and talukas are mandated to undertake 
SWM  and  WSS  design  and  implementation.  Stakeholder  selection  and 
consultation will therefore ensure their participation. Allow the stakeholders to 
nominate their own representatives, and ensure that all major stakeholder groups 
are represented.  
(ii)  Develop an issue assessment in consultation with all major stakeholder groups. 
Identify major sectoral issues: where the stakeholders disagree and where they 
may be able to find common ground. Explore issues that affect the formulation of 
a sector strategy and the development of a project investment, and summarize 
views in an issue matrix. Define the detailed methodology for the consensus-
building  efforts.  Circulate  the  draft  issue  assessment  to  all  participants  for 
comments and translate the final version to be made available to all participants. 
(iii)  Coordinate a consensus group that includes all the stakeholders identified. The 
participants, wherever possible, should be high-level staff, capable of making 
commitments on behalf of their organization. The gender balance of the group 
should be considered. Establish a schedule and reserve a venue for a series of 
consensus meetings, preferably in a neutral location. Prepare the agenda for 
each  meeting  to  focus  on  specific  issues,  with  specific  target  outputs.  The 
participants for each thematic session may be varied to focus the discussion, but 
the outputs of each session will be shared with the entire consensus group. 
(iv)  Clearly lay out the ground rules for the process at the beginning of each meeting, 
the basis for decision making, and the target output. A single text process will be 
used  to  document  the  proceedings.  All  participants  will  be  given  equal 
opportunity and encouragement to participate. All attempts will be made to reach 
consensus  on  every  important  issue.  The  consultants  will  clearly  document, 
summarize, and seek agreement on the output of each session. The summary of 
the output of the meeting will be circulated to the entire group the day after each 
meeting, and any final comments will be incorporated. 
(v)  Circulate the issue assessment together with draft policy at least 1 week before 
the first consensus meeting. The issues to be discussed and resolved through 
the consensus meetings will include (a) a realistic sector strategy and action plan 
for  WSS  and  SWM  sectors,  based  on  actual  resources  available;  (b)  the 
institutional mechanisms most suitable for delivery schemes, clearly defining the 
roles of each stakeholder; (c) a strategy for effectively mobilizing communities, 
with  focus  on  involving  women;  (d)  optimal  strategy  for  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M), addressing institutional and financial sustainability issues, 
as well as the need for major repairs; (f) sustainable mechanisms for monitoring 
and evaluation. Other factors may also be considered, based on the discussions 
of the group. In developing the solutions, the consultant or facilitator may use

Appendix 3  13 
problem trees, logical frameworks, or other similar project design tools, to guide 
and focus the process. 
 
C.  Formulation of Provincial Policies, Strategies, and Action Plans for SWM and WSS 
(i)  Based on the review, views collected through a participatory approach, national 
policies, and operational and institutional objectives for different areas in Sindh, 
identify  collection  of  overall  objectives  for  SWM  and  WSS  for  Sindh  and 
formulate provincial policies. 
(ii)  Develop SWM and WSS strategies for the different districts in Sindh, assessing 
urban and rural needs and opportunities. The document should be presented as 
a comprehensive document for Sindh, but the issues should address separately 
the perceived needs. Special attention should be paid to the following: 
(a)  Compile  and  present  a  number  of  best-practice  cases,  identify  and 
evaluate appropriate technologies and affordable management options 
for different scenarios (e.g., different opportunities for domestic, medical, 
industrial, hazardous waste) for SWM and WSS, considering subsidiarity, 
environmental sustainability principles, and access to the poor. Consider 
O&M requirements as part of technology selection, and define carefully 
objectives for site selection and coverage.  
(b)  Recommend legal and institutional arrangements for SWM and WSS to 
promote  public  participation.  Review  the  impacts  of  policy 
recommendations  on  the  poor  and  suggest  most  appropriate  coping 
mechanisms. Consider models for inter- and intra-municipal cooperation. 
(c)  Evaluate  financial  options  for  SWM  and  WSS,  considering  funding 
modalities, affordability analysis, tariff coverage, waste taxes and disposal 
levies, charge and rebate system, producer responsibility, subsidies for 
waste  prevention  and  water  conservation,  tax  preferences,  liability 
instruments,  cost  effectiveness  parameters  and  principles,  community 
contribution and participation.  
(d)  Formulate strategy for public awareness programs for SWM and WSS, 
identifying  best  communication  means  and  practices.  Assess  health, 
hygiene,  and  sanitation  benefits  and  impact  of  waste  reduction  and 
separation resulting from greater public awareness. 
(e)  Develop private sector participation options and opportunities for a variety 
of players (CBOs, small contractors, NGOs, suppliers, service contracts, 
management  contracts,  leases,  concessions,  build-operate-transfer,  or 
divestiture) as a function of size of the activities, presence or absence of 
participants, constraints, and local needs. Identify any legal or regulatory 
restrictions, domestic or foreign, on private participation and suggestions 
for overcoming. Develop objectives and parameters to promote private 
sector participation and investment.  
 
(iii)  Develop detailed Sindh action plans for SWM and WSS,1 setting out measures to 
be taken over the medium term (5–7 years). The action plans are to build upon 
detailed  identification  and  evaluation  options  undertaken  during  review  and

D.  Objectives and Methodology for SWM Tariff Administration Guidelines 
(i)  Review existing and past tariff structure and tariff user-fee levels for SWM and 
WSS services in various areas, and the system of billing being used. Conduct 
social surveys to determine affordability levels and the public’s willingness to pay.  
(ii)  Review social and financial objectives used to determine solid waste and WSS 
tariffs.  Specifically,  determine  suitable  levels  of  cross-subsidization  between 
customers.  
(iii)  Review  and  present  to  stakeholders  a  number  of  international  best-practice 
cases. Assess, through discussions with stakeholders, the extent to which the 
billing systems and financial management capabilities of cities may be used for 
cost recovery. 
(iv)  Assess the division of responsibilities among central, provincial, and municipal 
government agencies for funding arrangements, in the preparation and review of 
tariff  setting  proposals,  and  compliance  monitoring.  Consider  budgetary 
constraints and institutional capacities of agencies involved in the process. 
(v)  Develop social and financial objectives for the agencies and enterprises, NGOs, 
and CBOs responsible for collection and disposal of solid waste and for WSS.
